normalised: Telecommunications: Fiber to Home Expansion Gains Momentum in India

unnormalised: **Telecommunications: Fiber-to-Home Expansion Gains Momentum in India**
normalised: New Delhi, October twenty six, two thousand and twenty three – Fiber to the Home (F T T H) infrastructure development is rapidly expanding across India, spearheaded by both private players and government initiatives. Bharti Airtel announced today the completion of five thousand kilometer of fiber optic cable laying in the Delhi N C R region alone, connecting over twenty thousand homes with high speed internet.

unnormalised: New Delhi, October 26, 2023 – Fiber-to-the-Home (FTTH) infrastructure development is rapidly expanding across India, spearheaded by both private players and government initiatives. Bharti Airtel announced today the completion of 5000 km of fiber optic cable laying in the Delhi-NCR region alone, connecting over 20,000 homes with high-speed internet.
normalised: Reliance Jio continues its aggressive rollout strategy, targeting Tier two and Tier three cities with affordable F T T H plans. Doctor Rajesh Kumar, a telecom analyst at the Indian Institute of Technology (I I T) Kanpur, notes that "Increased F T T H penetration is crucial for supporting India's growing digital economy, enabling e-commerce, remote work, and online education."

unnormalised: Reliance Jio continues its aggressive rollout strategy, targeting Tier-II and Tier-III cities with affordable FTTH plans. Dr. Rajesh Kumar, a telecom analyst at the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Kanpur, notes that "Increased FTTH penetration is crucial for supporting India's growing digital economy, enabling e-commerce, remote work, and online education."
normalised: The BharatNet project, a government initiative, aims to connect all gram panchayats with broadband. While progress has been slower than initially projected, recent reports indicate renewed focus and increased funding.

unnormalised: The BharatNet project, a government initiative, aims to connect all gram panchayats with broadband. While progress has been slower than initially projected, recent reports indicate renewed focus and increased funding.
normalised: Meanwhile, local cable operators (L C O) are also upgrading their networks to offer F T T H services, often focusing on localized areas with high population density, such as the bustling market areas of Chandni Chowk, requiring careful planning within the congested approximately one hundred square feet shops. Competition in the F T T H market is expected to intensify, driving down prices and benefiting consumers. Expect monthly plans to start below rupee five hundred in many areas.

unnormalised: Meanwhile, local cable operators (LCOs) are also upgrading their networks to offer FTTH services, often focusing on localized areas with high population density, such as the bustling market areas of Chandni Chowk, requiring careful planning within the congested ~100 sq ft shops. Competition in the FTTH market is expected to intensify, driving down prices and benefiting consumers. Expect monthly plans to start below Rs. 500 in many areas.
